headline: Pork Fried Rice
description: This pork fried rice recipe with carrots, broccoli, and peas is flavored with garlic and ginger for a quick and easy way to enjoy leftover rice.

video.description: A quick and easy one-skillet dish perfect for weeknight suppers.
video.name: Pork Fried Rice

name: Pork Fried Rice
recipeIngredient: 1 (6 ounce) boneless pork loin chop, cut into small pieces

recipeInstructions.text: Melt butter in a large non-stick skillet over medium heat. Add pork, green onion, carrot, and broccoli; cook and stir until pork is cooked through, 7 to 10 minutes. Transfer pork mixture to a bowl and return skillet to medium heat.

Stir egg into the skillet and scramble until completely set. Add pork mixture back into the skillet; stir in rice, peas, soy sauce, garlic powder, and ground ginger. Cook and stir until heated through, 7 to 10 minutes.

review.reviewBody: I make this a lot but I lost my recipe, so it's a good thing I had it saved in my favorites. It is one of the few dishes I can get my Mom to eat. She has lost her sense of taste but she still loves this dish. Thank you so much for sharing this dish. God Bless You!
I made it following the recipe closely, but by eye rather than exact measurements. I added celery and beansprouts. Very good and will add it to my recipe file. (I'd add a photo but we ate it all.)
It was amazing.
My family loved it
Great recipe. I tripled the size for my crew and added a tablespoon of hot spicy sesame oil into a large wok before the butter was added. Came out great. Thank you.

I have made this recipe many times with Trader Joe's Mandarin Orange Chicken. I've made it using pork, chicken and my smoked pork and all have been delicious. I do mix my liquid and dry spices together before I add them to the pan.

It was very easy to make and as usual I added my own types of veggies but they went well with the rice and pork. I added canned water chestnuts and bamboo shoots. Then I had onion garlic green bell pepper and sliced carrots. It turned out really great

I made it today following MOST of the ingredients. I added some diced fresh mushrooms, Onions, Oyster sauce, Sesame oil and fresh minced ginger, Like Chef Arnold said, It's like stew adding different ingredients. First time using broccoli, but it worked well in the flavor profile. Good recipe to start creating your own version. I sprinkled some Calamansi (Phillippine lemon powder) over it when served..
I upped the servings to 4 & used 3.5 C rice
It was so good I put it in a bed of fresh spinach
It was so good.i had leftover pork and it worked beautifully with this recipe. Thank you.
Easy & well received by my family. My son requested I make it again. Replaced peas with broccoli. Appreciate the recipe!
This was absolutely delicious! For anyone that may have found the dish a bit bland, I highly recommend adding Thai Sweet Chile Sauce!

I love that it called for ingredients I usually have on hand, and it was super quick and easy to make. There was a little sum' sum' missing though, cant quite put my finger on it. Otherwise this would get 5 stars. Cost effective, quick, easy, pantry ingredients. Score!
It very easy to make. I used boneless pork chops I grilled a few days ago. It was DELICIOUS!!!!!!!!
Easy and delish. Will make again.
Quick and easy ! very tasty !
Simple, easy and delicious
Very good! I used leftover pork tenderloin and followed the recipe exactly. Better than take out!

I made this and I really liked it. I never follow recipes to the letter, so I adjusted some but the recipe was a good starting point. I used vegetable broth to make my rice; I liked the added flavor. I used sesame oil to prepare my pork.
Nice and easy! Love it!!!
Quick and easy! I used leftover pork. Not bad at all!

I double or triple the veggies, omit the green onion (not something I use often; can't justify buying a whole bunch of 'em for such a small amount), and sometimes skip the egg. Love this - it was an instant family favorite.
Loved this! Turned out as good as any I’ve gotten from a Chinese restaurant. I just threw in some frozen mixed veggies with the green onion so no chopping necessary.
Simply excellent as is!
Quick and easy... I 4X’d the recipe for left overs ..

This was the first time I had made any fried rice dish, and it turned out absolutely awesome. I did make several changes however - I used 1 package of omnipork (plant-based product) instead of pork, added about 1/2 cup of veggies instead of 1/4 cup, and used sesame oil instead of butter to the wok to start. I didn't have any powdered ginger, so used fresh grated ginger (about 3/4 tsp). It tasted amazing. It was a bit salty however due to the soy sauce. If you are looking for less salty, change the soy to light soy.
This is a great recipe as written. The only changes I made were to salt and pepper (to taste) the scrambled eggs. I also added ½ tsp of turmeric for color.
Used some ground pork we had. Good easy stuff!
Very easy to make.
It was good but not our favorite. Seemed like it was missing something.

Excellent base fried rice recipe. It can be adapted in any number of ways and is very flexible based on your own tastes. The only thing I would list as a firm change is the use of butter. Nope! Smoke point is too low with butter and it’s not the right flap or for this dish. Toasted sesame
Very versatile!. I used leftover pprk loin snd added sone chopped celery. Easy. Quick and delicious!
I added a lil bit more green onion also some yellow onions I doubled the recipe and used three eggs instead of two
Nice quick meal. I’ll definitely make it again.

This is a quick and delicious recipe. I had left over pork tenderloin roast and I used a package of frozen rice and vegetables plus onion and red pepper. Since others thought the recipe, I used Sesame Oil instead of butter and doubled the soy sauce, ginger and garlic powder. I will definitely make it again.
Very tasty! Great way to transform leftovers into a quick meal.
Good recipe. I increased the vegetables, added another egg and sprinkled on some fish sauce as well as the soy sauce.
I added an egg, some sesame oil, and chili powder! Great dish!
I used spicy shrimp instead of pork and it was delish...my family loved it...everyone had seconds and finished the rest off for breakfast.
Both 10 year old boys started with, "I hate rice! I'm not eating dinner!" And ended with finishing their third serving.
I love this recipe. I never know what to do with all the pork chops my husband buys but this is a great way to use them. I always double the recipe, it's still good even the next day
I added mushrooms!

This was very good. I used leftover pork chops and doubled the ingredients. I also added some mushrooms and a tomato that needed to be used. Also fresh garlic and ginger. Finally, I added about 1/4 tsp. of red pepper flakes.

The broccoli was overpowering so I was very disappointed as I love fried rice. It just doesn't belong there. I added it at the very end so was very careful that it wasn't overcooked but still all I could taste was broccoli. Should have served it on the side.
Turned out great. Used a couple of boneless pork chops.

This was really good. I made it as stated but left out the broccoli because I really don't think I've ever had broccoli in my fried rice. I also used brown rice. I really like this recipe because it tastes healthier and lighter than others I've tried. I'll make it again just like I did this time.
I marinaded the cut up pork in Golden Italian dressing over night and substituted the peas with corn and it tastes great!

This recipe was great! I increased veggies to 1/3 cup and added 1/3 cup of diced summer squash. I also doubled the rice, added more soy and a heavy of drizzle of olive oil at the end to increase moisture. Also I did all of this in one pan after sautéing the vegetables I move them out of the center of the pan and put in two whisked eggs (instead of one) then as it cooked mixed it back in with the sautéed veggies from around the edge of the pan and then added rice and remaining ingredients.

As many others have said, this is a very bland recipe. It is meant for those who have the very basic ingredients onhand. If you're going to make chinese dishes, keep some oyster sauce and sesame oil in the pantry.
Didn't have soy sauce so I substitute teriyaki instead. Came out ok. Will make again.

This is fine, but a little bland. I added sesame oil as others suggested. It is a good use of extra pork , but I wouldn't make this as my first use of pork (e.g., one night, slow cook a porkloin for pulled BBQ pork, save half for this before adding BBQ). I'd probably add more ginger or introduce garlic sauce.
I added corn, broccoli, bean sprouts, carrots, celery, and green onions. Seasoned to taste. Delicious!
Very good...I added twice the pork and twice the rice, but otherwise followed the directions closely!
Like others I added hoisin sauce, sesame oil, fresh garlic and cooked rice in chicken broth. Everyone loved this recipe and it’s definitely a keeper.

I will be using this from now on. I made this exactly as the recipe called for. I omitted the broccoli and added sweet yellow onions chopped wide. I also used left over pork chops and left over baked chicken that was well seasoned. I turned out delicious.
We all liked it! I will definitely make this again.
Fantastic! Even better than take out, by far. I can adjust the ingredients I like and customize to myself. Very quick and easy.
Very easy to make - delicious to eat...
delicious.

I used a wok and pushed all of the ingredients aside. Then I added a little more butter to the side of the wok to scramble the egg to save a step. I would use this recipe for leftover chicken, beef, shrimp, anything!
Followed recipe except for carrots since I didn't have any. Delicious and easy.

This was EXCELLENT. The only changes I made was I used up a Chinese marinated pork chop instead of cooking the pork from scratch and added that and fresh ginger and garlic to the cooked vegetables (instead of powder). My husband LOVED it!!!
Pearl River Bridge soy sauce (I use light), makes a great flavor profile.

So apparently in my house this serves two! I did shove two tablespoons in my face before the boys ate it all and my daughter wanted something else thank goodness! They loved it and I would have eaten a bowl joyfully. I have to make gluten free and it was great. Tripling it next time.

It got eaten so fast, I made it again the next day! I just omitted the broccoli because I didn’t have that on hand. I added in extra egg than it called for. I had leftover pork chops from the day before, so I just pulled the meat apart on them and used that. I thought I had frozen peas but turns out I didn’t, so I just substituted a can of peas instead. Still came out really good. So simple to make.
Good.

I did everything as instructed except the frozen peas. Step #1 added the peas and the last step added the peas again. I knew better and did not add in the first step.They would have been mushy and taken over the taste of the whole dish. Otherwise, it was great! BTW the cooked rice I used was cooked in Veg. broth which gave it an extra zing. Thanks

I make this all the time! It is a five star recipe exactly as is, but I will share some things I do sometimes to change it up/make it easier. I always use at least day old rice. I also always use frozen mixed veggies (corn, green beans, carrots, peas). Soooo easy. I use whatever protein I have on hand (chicken, pork, sausage, steak, sometimes just extra eggs). For the addition of eggs, I make an omelette into which I grate fresh ginger (kept in the freezer) and garlic. Like I said, I have made it many times just as stated and it is superb. I thank this recipe for helping me to realize that I can successfully make delicious fried rice at home!
Good. I used chopped up leftover pork roast and added it after sauteeing the vegetables. I used brown basmati rice and increased all quantities. 2/4 kids ate, which is a win around here these days.

I made so many changes, but still a good recipe to get the idea of ingredients needed. I used more rice & veggies. Cooked the pork loin in the crock pot w/ chopped ginger, onion and chicken broth, then shredded it after cooking. other reviews mention sesame oil & hoisin, I'll give that a try next time.
It came out great. Next time I will double the recipe. There wasn't any left after four people ate.

Flawless recipe for those who like the original recipe, but I had to adjust it for three leftover barbecue pork chops and nearly half a saucepan of leftover rice. We had frozen peas and broccoli in the freezer. It needed much more than the suggested garlic and ginger powder. I threw in nearly as much fish sauce, and a tablespoon of szechuan peppercorn powder and, seriously, 4 tablespoons of Chinese Hot Oil. It wasn't very spicy at all, but seriously umami. It was so easy that I will continue to buy pork chops in bulk and, three days later, make this. Next time I will toss in Hunan chilis.
I used leftover pork tenderloin that I diced and sautéed in a small amount of olive oil. The meal was great!

Tasty. As good as any I have eaten in a restaurant. This recipe is very easy and fast. Not too many ingredients so it is budget friendly. . I used brown rice. This is perfect for weeknights when you are needing a fast meal. I cooked enough extra rice to freeze for the next time I prepare this.

pork stew meat diced and browned w green onion and garlic, bacon, diced mushrooms and broccoli.
set aside added rice to pan with scrambled egg soy and some 5 spice, was great.

Great one-dish meal! I added sliced celery, substituted edamame for the peas, added 2 tsp. finely chopped fresh ginger to the vegetable-pork mixture while they sauteed. (Omitted the ginger powder.) Next time I'll add sliced shiitakes. Yum!
Added fresh garlic instead, and more of it, and did it all in one pan: best idea. Soy sauce is to taste. Would recommend adding a little soy sauce to the eggs before scrambling them.
Love the recipe. We used what we had on hand and it turned out great. Leftover pork chops worked well. Cooked up with the onion then added a bag of stir fry veggies.
Good I think. Spilled the soy sauce bottle into the mic
It was great; however, some added salt may help improve the bland taste.

Good Recipe! I seem to always have to double the seasonings on all the recipes from this site. Maybe my family has weak taste buds, but I always double the quantity of the flavor-adding elements (onions, garlic powder, soy sauce etc. ). This is a great base recipe though and I can see how you can add a whole host of different proteins and vegetables in (I used shrimp). I will definitely make it again.

This makes a smaller portion. I quadrupled it for my house #momto3boys. I used fresh garlic and mixed that and the ginger into the soy sauce before adding it. I also seasoned the pork before cooking. I used fresh minced onion, which totally worked, because I wasn't running to the store for a few green onions. I could see that being a nice addition to the dish. Finally, wasn't going wait for the rice to chill - it went in hot. Still good!
This turned out to be a Great recipe. Made it as written. Adjusted for 4. There was No Leftovers.
Great recipe! Great flavor! Easy to make.
You really need to use sticky rice. It's the only way to cook any asian dish.
AWESOME WILL PASS IN ON TO MY FRIENDS AND I WIIL Make IT AGAIN

I left out the broccoli and used red rice the first time and used brown rice the next time. Came out great both times, I really liked the red rice version, different taste for sure. Make sure you always use cold cooked rice.
This is a versatile, quick recipe. My only change was to use two fresh garlic cloves because I didn’t have ground garlic on hand. It still came out really well.

Made it with leftover pork tenderloin, doubling basic recipe. Cooked 1 C. jasmine rice with 1 + 1/2 cup water (makes 3 cups). Scrambled 2 eggs & cooked flat, then cut into thin strips. Sauteed diced carrots, onion, garlic, broccoli & 1/2 tsp ginger powder in 1 T butter + 1 T veg oil + 1/2 tsp. sesame oil until veggies were tender crisp. Added diced pork tenderloin + 1/2 cup frozen peas, stirred until heated thru. Added pre-cooked eggs, , 3 T soy sauce + 1 T hoisin sauce & stirred until heated thru. Delish! Hubby and I both loved it! Will definitely make again!
Very easy and delicious. Will definitely make again
I used sesame oil and left out the egg
I followed all directions with the exception of grating and squeezing the ginger. My family loved it and I will be repeating this recipe for fun food occasions.

I used this recipe as a foundation for shrimp fried rice. Fortunately we had lots of veggies on hand so I threw in cauliflower and broccoli florets, and some baby spinach as well. The other addition was a shot of oyster sauce which gave a sweet background flavor to what could have been a bit of a bland recipe. Oh, and frozen precooked shrimp topped off the meal. I fried them with the veggies and my wife asked for seconds, the real indication of success.
I used leftover pork tender loin heated and it was great.
Made it like the recipe but used a combination of sesame oil and vegetable oil in place of butter. Turned out great. Family loved it.
Nice and easy recipe. It was a little bland, but I'll just add more spices next time. This goes in the rotation. Thanks!

I'm not a fan of pork at all and the first time I made this it turned out so good! I didn't have any broccoli so I substituted it with celery. This has just the right amount of spices and it really turned out great so I am making again tonight. Thank you for the recipe, I wouldn't change a thing but for using your favorite veggies on hand! :)
I used fresh ginger and garlic, which enhanced the flavor. It's a good, satisfying side dish.
